questions.text: A 45 year old female patient had STEMI and was treated for the same. She was put on Atorvastatin, dual Antiplatelet therapy, GTN during the attack, and a beta blocker on discharge. Which of the following beta blocker should not be prescribed for the above patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pindolol In patients with Ischemic heart disease, we need to avoid beta-blockers with intrinsic Sympathomimetic properties, because they will partially stimulate Beta 1 and increase the workload on the Heart So in the option pindolol is a beta blocker with intrinsic Sympathomimetic property Avoid beta-blockers with intrinsic Sympathomimetic properties in migraine and IHD Patients.

Highyeild:

Beta-blockers with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (or partial agonistic activity): Celiprolol Pindolol Alprenolol Acebutalol These are less efficacious but they have less chance of causing severe bradycardia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Metoprolol ( Option A ), Celiprolol ( Option C ), and Nebivolol ( Option D ) are selective Beta 1 blockers or cardioselective or 2nd generation beta blockers. They do not have any intrinsic agonistic activity, unlike pindolol.

Extraedge:

Partial beta-agonist: Pindolol, acebutalol, celiprolol, carteolol, bopindolol, oxprenolol, and penbutolol: Major CVS applications - less plasma lipid action and bradycardia Intrinsic sympathomimetic activity However, doubtful clinical benefit Esmolol: partial agonist and MSA Ultra short acting (less than 10 minutes) - inactivated by esterases in blood Degree of blockade can be titrated - Steady dose can be maintained Given as IV infusion in SVT, AF, Atrial flutter, arrhythmia during anaesthesia and cardiac surgery etc. Available as injections IV: 100-500 mg/10 ml inj.

questions.text: A 5 year Child presented to the emergency department after ingesting multiple tablets of metoprolol. The child Presented with profound hypotension and bradycardia. What is the specific antidote used in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glucagon

Highyeild:

From the above case history it’s a clear case of Beta blocker (metoprolol) poisoning. Glucagon is a specific antidote for beta-blocker toxicity: In beta-blocker poisoning beta receptors are blocked in the heart leading to a decrease in HR, FOC, and conduction So GPCR of the Beta 1 receptor in the heart is blocked, so what to do now? Give a drug that acts through different types of GPCR So, Glucagon acts through its own GPCR, independent of the β adrenergic receptor, and has chronotropic and inotropic effects on the heart In beta-blocker poisoning glucagon is a physiological antidote

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Atropine (Option A) , Adrenaline (Option C), and Isoprenaline (Option D) are not SPECIFIC antidotes for beta-blocker poisoning. Although they can have similar actions they are not much effective.

Extraedge:

Why Not Atropine An Antidote As It Also Increases Hr And Conduction It is not much effective compared to Glucagon and does not increase FOC It is used if there is bradycardia

Patients taking beta-blockers have more severe or treatment- refractory anaphylaxis Dose: 1 mg IV q5min, then 5-15 mcg/min IV infusion Increase HR and cardiac output Mechanism Non-adrenergic pathway Stimulate adenylate cyclase to produce cyclic AMP (calcium- dependent stimulation) Positive ionotropic and chronotropic effects Adverse Effects: nausea, vomiting A medication (hormone) given by injection that is used to treat severe low blood sugar Glucagon comes in a kit. The kit includes: A small bottle (vial) that contains glucagon. The glucagon is a dry powder. A syringe that contains 1 cc of sterile liquid.

questions.text: A patient 56yr old was on metoprolol and amlodipine for stable angina for one year. He was on Atorvastatin and aspirin for dyslipidemia, and metformin for DMT2. He suddenly stopped taking all medication as he felt better after 1 year. He came to OPD with complaints of nervousness, tachycardia, and increased intensity of chest pain, and on measuring BP was High. This was due to the sudden stoppage of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metoprolol

Highyeild:

When β blockers are discontinued after prolonged regular use, patients experience a withdrawal syndrome, manifested by nervousness, tachycardia, increased intensity of angina, and an increase of blood pressure. Even myocardial infarction occurred in a few cases The withdrawal syndrome is due to upregulation or super sensitivity of β adrenoceptor. Following abrupt withdrawal, the normal concentrations of circulating catecholamines Have access to an increased population of beta-adrenoceptors due to the up-regulation of Receptors that lead to withdrawal symptoms. Therefore, β blockers should not be discontinued abruptly. If a patient is switching to another group of antihypertensives, there should be a gradual tapering of beta blockers

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Amlodipine is dihydropyridine. By inhibiting the calcium channel, these agents decrease the frequency of opening of the calcium channel leading to vasodilation and also decrease the activity of the heart. Option: C. The activity of HMG CoA reductase is maximum at night, so these drugs are administered at night. Rosuvastatin (t=19 hours) and atorvastatin (t=14 hours) are long-acting drugs, therefore can be administered at any time of the day. In addition to lipid-lowering effects, statins also possess additional antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-proliferative properties. These are known as pleiotropic effects of statins and are responsible, in part for lowering the risk of stroke and MI. Pravastatin also causes a decrease in plasma fibrinogen levels. Option: D. Metformin and phenformin are biguanides and are preferred agents for obese patients (as these are weight neutral and may even cause weight loss). These drugs decrease blood glucose by activating AMPK (Adenosine Monophosphate-activated protein Kinase) that helps in decreasing the production (inhibit gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis) and increasing the utilization (stimulation of glycolysis and tissue uptake of glucose).

M2 AND M3 AGONIST We conclude that M (2) and M (3) receptor expression within the same cell undergoes differential agonist-induced regulation being accompanied by distinct regulation of G-protein expression leading to differential effects on signal transduction by other receptor systems.
